title: 3,500,000 Articles
synopsis: We retrieved the English Wikipedia current-articles-only xml dump sometime in 2011. We extract title and text elements for each article. We'll develop a variety of useful parsers while we understand there is no reliable spec for markup. [http://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Markup_spec wikipedia]

title: Academic topics
synopsis: These are various academic topics that I'm currently involved in

title: Alternate Vision
synopsis: Mike Caulfield writes in "Smallest Federated Wiki as an Alternate Vision of the Web" that after three weeks of using our reimagining of the wiki (and really, of the web) that we undermine some of the basic premises of the web; and how good that feels. [http://hapgood.us/2014/06/04/smallest-federated-wiki-as-an-alternate-vision-of-the-web/ post]

title: Approaches to meta-language implementation
synopsis: The main approach I have been discussing with Heiko is to design the language from the bottom using a grammar, implement this using either a parser generator or a parsing library, and finally have a translation component that translates the meta-language parse tree into each target language (using some kind of look-up table for each language)

title: BSc project
synopsis: My Bsc project is a contribution to the open source project Shogun. [https://github.com/shogun-toolbox/shogun GitHub]. [http://www.shogun-toolbox.org Website].

title: Convex Optimisation
synopsis: A page with 0 items.

title: Doing it For Free
synopsis: Portland Monthly and the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry (OMSI) joined forces for just such an exploration. We queried our readers and experts in numerous fields to put together a list of 130 leading Oregon innovators, then assembled a panel of five community leaders with a wide-angle view of the future. [http://www.portlandmonthlymag.com/arts-and-entertainment/articles/oregonians-changing-our-world-october-2011 post]

title: Esben SÃ¸rig
synopsis: Currently a computer science student in London. Owns this wiki to experiment with the federated wiki concept.

title: Ethical Machines
synopsis: [http://aitopics.org/sites/default/files/classic/Machine_Intelligence_10/MI10-Ch29-Good.pdf pdf]

title: Exploratory Parsing
synopsis: See [https://github.com/AboutUs/devblog/blob/master/_posts/2011-07-03-getting-started-exploratory-parsing.markdown Getting Started] blog post announcing the open-sourcing of this technology.

title: Forking as liking
synopsis: When you browse the federation, you connect to many different servers. If you discover a page that you want to be able to get back to,  it is good practice to fork the page to your own wiki.

title: How To Wiki
synopsis: This is our help documentation. Read a little bit. Then move on to our [http://sandbox.fed.wiki.org Sandbox] and give your new knowledge a workout. Still confused? Look through our our [[Frequently Asked Questions]].

title: Humane Software
synopsis: The rise of explorable explanations. [http://www.maartenlambrechts.be/the-rise-of-explorable-explanations/ html]

title: Improving federated wiki
synopsis: Here I discuss things that I think would improve federated wiki. I do not yet understand all technical details of federated wiki's implementation, nor am I aware of all the reasoning behind the design choices of federated wiki, so some of these discussions may not carry much value in case they have emerged from a lack of understanding.

title: Javascript Jabber
synopsis: Ward discusses federated wiki with the Jabber panel Charles Max Wood, Jamison Dance and Dave Smith.

title: Learning federated wiki
synopsis: I've found that the best resource for learning the basics of federated wiki is the page on [[Things You Must Do]].

title: Linear Algebra
Lost My Origin
synopsis: Mike Caulfield reports, after watching four dozen or so people play around with federated wiki in various contexts, I think I can identify the biggest problem: loss of write context, and the sad cycle of errors that result.

title: Machine Learning
synopsis: [[Representer theorem]]

title: Norvig on Chomsky
synopsis: On Chomsky and the Two Cultures of Statistical Learning wherein Norvig responds to Chomsky's remarks in response to Steven Pinker's question about the success of probabilistic models trained with statistical methods. [http://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/myl/PinkerChomskyMIT.html chomsky] [http://norvig.com/chomsky.html norvig]

title: Norvig on Data
synopsis: Peter Norvig, et al. "The Unreasonable Effectiveness of Data" in IEEE Intelligent Systems (2011) [http://static.googleusercontent.com/media/research.google.com/en/us/pubs/archive/35179.pdf pdf]

title: Notes on first time use of federated wiki
synopsis: The frontend of the federated wiki seems quite unstable. I have experienced making edits on pages that are not saved. This is probably an issue with the interface not properly giving feedback as to when it has actually saved edits.

title: Notes on the Smallest Federated Wiki
synopsis: These are my notes from using the Smallest Federated Wiki.

title: One Hour Wikipedia
synopsis: Channeling both Chomsky and Norvig I routinely consult Wikipedia by reading it in its entirety to answer questions no one had thought to pose.

title: Papers
synopsis: I. J. Good - [[Ethical Machines]]

title: People I follow
synopsis: These are the people I follow

title: Project plan
synopsis: Title: Contribution to the Shogun Machine Learning Toolbox: a Meta-Language for Automatic Shogun Example Generation

title: Question: How can I merge changes from forks?
synopsis: There are approximately a billion copies of [[Happening Folks]]. How can we integrate the changes into a shared version, assuming we want to? I don't even know which version I've linked to.

title: Recent Changes
synopsis: Here we list neighborhood pages with those most recently changed listed first. See also [[Local Changes]].

title: Representer theorem
synopsis: The minimiser of a regularised empirical error is a linear combination of the inputs.

title: Running a local federated wiki
synopsis: It's easy to run a wiki on your local machine. The local wiki will not be visible to others on the web, but it will be part of your own neighbourhood, meaning you can link/fork/etc to wikis on the web from the local wiki and all drag-drop features work between local and public wikis.

title: Shut Up Inner Critic
synopsis: John Hopkins surgeon Charles Limb analyzed brain scans of jazz musicians to try to identify the brain activity indicators of creativity. His results suggest their creativity highs are correlated at times when their self criticism activity is low (they have muffled the voice of the [[Impostor Syndrome]]).

title: Statistical Modeling Cultures
synopsis:
Statistical Modeling: The Two Cultures by
Leo Breiman.
One culture assumes that the data are generated
bya given stochastic data model. The other uses algorithmic models and
treats the data mechanism as unknown. [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.156.4933&rep=rep1&type=pdf pdf]

title: Things You Must Do
synopsis: You can wander all day in the federation, and it's easy to get sidetracked. Here we link you directly to the things you must be do/be able to do before the March Happening, in a nice linear style. You can still wander if you want, but if you want to do the minimum, go through this list, skip the byways, and you will be set.
